DataElement.preferredDefinition: Information related to the methods used for capturing images when the sample is able to function as an image contrast agent and the type of data acquisition device used in an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The type of data acquisition device used in an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.:A number of things or events standing or succeeding in order, and connected by a like relation. (from On-line Medical Dictionary)

Concepts.definition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.
A group or succession of objects, substances, or events arranged in regular order in space or time, connected by a like relation, or forming a kind of chain.

Property.preferredDefinition: A specific manner, characteristic, pattern of application or the employment of, any therapeutic agent or method of treatment, especially involving the physical treatment of a condition.

Concepts.definition: A specific manner, characteristic, pattern of application or the employment of, any therapeutic agent or method of treatment, especially involving the physical treatment of a condition.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

DataElementConcept.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 4/30/09 created per VCDE Equipment CDE set small group to include "image" as a qualifier in the OC.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A list of specific methods used for capturing images when the sample is able to function as an image contrast agent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The emission of light in an organism through a physiological process or in an experimental system that mimics the physiological conditions.

Concepts.definition: The production of light by certain living organisms, including fireflies and phytoplankton, by the conversion of chemical to radiant energy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths between 750 nanometers and 1 millimeter, between those of visible light and microwaves. This portion of the electromagnetic spectrum can usually be sensed as heat.

Concepts.definition: Electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths between 750 nanometers and 1 millimeter, between those of visible light and microwaves. This portion of the electromagnetic spectrum can usually be sensed as heat.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Radiation of neutrons during radioactive decay.

Concepts.definition: Radiation of neutrons during radioactive decay.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Emission of electromagnetic energy with a shorter frequency (longer wavelength) than that of the incident monochromatic light.  Arises from the low probability absorption of quanta with a higher energy than that required for a transition: the difference in energy is emitted as a lower frequency (energy) photon.  Allows analysis of vibrational and rotational energy levels using visible incident light.

Concepts.definition: Emission of electromagnetic energy with a shorter frequency (longer wavelength) than that of the incident monochromatic light.  Arises from the low probability absorption of quanta with a higher energy than that required for a transition: the difference in energy is emitted as a lower frequency (energy) photon.  Allows analysis of vibrational and rotational energy levels using visible incident light.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of tomography in which gamma photon-emitting radionuclides are administered to the patient and then detected by one or more gamma cameras rotated around the patient. From the series of two-dimensional images produced, a three-dimensional image can be created by computer reconstruction.

Concepts.definition: A type of tomography in which gamma photon-emitting radionuclides are administered to the patient and then detected by one or more gamma cameras rotated around the patient. From the series of two-dimensional images produced, a three-dimensional image can be created by computer reconstruction.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique in which high-frequency sound waves are bounced off internal organs and the echo pattern is converted into a 2 dimensional picture of the structures beneath the transducer.

Concepts.definition: The use of high-frequency sound waves to generate images of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of high-energy radiation.  In low doses, x-rays are used to diagnose diseases by making pictures of the inside of the body.  In high doses, x-rays are used to treat cancer.

Concepts.definition: Ionizing electromagnetic radiation having a wavelength that is shorter than ultraviolet radiation and longer than gamma radiation.

Fluorescence is a luminescence (i.e., optical phenomenon) in cold bodies, in which a molecule absorbs a high-energy photon, and re-emits it as a lower-energy (longer-wavelength) photon. The energy difference between the absorbed and emitted photons ends up as molecular vibrations (heat).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The mode or manner or orderly sequence of events of a process or procedure.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: 10/2/11 Released caNanoLab v1.5 content per Sue Pan as part of model cleanup task.
